geometry_util module¶

geometry_util.create_jsr(ryr, layers)[source]¶

Create a jSR neighborhood from RyR locations.

jSR is assumed to be found surrounding RyR, a neighborhood is therefore made by first copying the RyR array and then padding it with the given number of layers.

Parameters:
  • ryr (numpy.ndarray) – A 2D boolean array of RyR locations
  • layers (int) – The number of jSR to pad around each RyR
Returns:

An array of jSR locations, of the same shape as the input RyR array
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
geometry_util.create_nsr(ryr, width=3)[source]¶

Create the nSR column 2D template by centering them around RyR.

The default nSR column width supposes that the RyR array has already been refined. If using an unrefined RyR array, the normal width would be 1.

Parameters:
  • ryr (numpy.ndarray) – A refined RyR array (12x12 microns)
  • width (int, optional) – The width of each nSR column around each RyR
geometry_util.pad_array(data, final_shape)[source]¶

Pad a 2D array with zeros to create an array of desired shape.

First an array of the desired shape is created and initialized to zero, then the input array is centered in the new array.

Parameters:
  • data (numpy.ndarray) – Input array
  • shape (tuple of int) – The shape of the output
Returns:

An array of the specificed output shape, with the input array at the center.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
geometry_util.plot_array(data, title='', psize=0.036, cmap='Greys_r', **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot a 2D array.

Parameters:
  • data (numpy.ndarray) – A array to be plotted
  • title (str, optional) – Title to add to the plot
  • psize (float, optional) – Size of each pixel in microns, relevant for labeling of the axis
  • **kwargs – Keyword argments to be passed along to matplotlib.pyplot.imshow
geometry_util.pprint_array(data, t='1', f='0')[source]¶

Pretty print a boolean 2D array.

Parameters:
  • data (numpy.ndarray) – A 2D boolean array to be printed
  • t (str, optional) – Symbol to use for true values
  • f (str, optional) – Symbol to use for false values
geometry_util.prune_ryrs(ryr, prune_inds)[source]¶

Remove RyRs specified by index.

The index of a ryr is given by the ordering of numpy.ndarray.nonzero.

Parameters:
  • ryr (numpy.ndarray) – Boolean 2D array of RyR locations
  • prune_inds (int or tuple of int) – Inidices of RyR to be pruned
Returns:

An array of same shape as input, with certain RyR removed.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
geometry_util.read_ppm(filename)[source]¶

Read a .ppm file and return a boolean array.

Parameters:filename (str) – Name of the infile.
Returns:A 2D boolean array, with shape given by input image.
Return type:numpy.ndarray
geometry_util.refine_jsr(jsr, subdivide=3, smoothen_corners=True, remove_edges=False)[source]¶

Increase resolution of jSR data.

A jSR array is refined by marking all subpixels as jSR. For subpixels belonging to a pixel not originally marked as jSR, but being located at a ‘corner’, this corner can be partially filled in to get a smoother jSR after refinement. If the jSR extends to the borders of the image, the outermost edge of subpixels can also be trimmed.

The standard case is that the input image is given with a resolution of 36x36 microns per pixel. Each pixel is then split into 9 pixels of size 12x12 microns.

Parameters:
  • jsr (numpy.ndarray) – Array designating location of jSR
  • subdivide (int, optional) – The number of subpixels each pixel is divided into, must be odd numbered
  • smoothen_corners (bool, optional) – If true, corners in the refinement are smoothed
  • remove_edges (bool, optional) – Remove all jSR subpixels at the outermost edge of the array
Returns:

Athe 2D boolean array of larger shape than input.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray2
geometry_util.refine_ryr(ryr, subdivide=3)[source]¶

Increase resolution of RyR array.

A RyR array is refined by marking only the center subpixel as a RyR.

The standard case is that the input image is given with a resolution of 36x36 microns per pixel. Each pixel is then split into 9 pixels of size 12x12 microns.

Parameters:
  • ryr (numpy.ndarray) – A 2D boolean array denoting RyR locations, most likely in 36x36 micron resolution
  • subdivide (int, optional) – The number of subpixels each pixel is divided into, must be odd numbered
Returns:

A 2D boolean array of larger shape than input.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
geometry_util.save_combined_2D_pdf(filename, ryr, jsr, nsr, psize=0.012, cmap='Greys_r')[source]¶

Create a pdf of the combined 2D arrays overlaid each other.

All arrays should be refined, i.e., 12x12 nm resolution.

Parameters:
  • filename (str) – Basename of the resulting pdf file
  • ryr (numpy.ndarray) – Location of RyR
  • jsr (numpy.ndarray) – Location of jSR
  • nsr (numpy.ndarray) – Location of nSR
  • psize (float, optional) – Size of each pixel in microns, relevant for labeling of the axis
  • cmap (str, optional) – Name of matplotlib colormap to use.
geometry_util.shrink_sr(sr, layers)[source]¶

Shrink SR by the given number of layers.

Parameters:
  • sr (numpy.ndarray) – the boolean 2D array to be shrunk
  • layers (int) – number of layers to shrink
Returns:

An array of the same shape as the input, with the SR shrunk.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
geometry_util.trim_to_bbox(data, flip=True)[source]¶

Trim a boolean 2D array down to its bounding box.

Parameters:
  • data (numpy.ndarray) – A boolean 2D array
  • flip (bool, optional) – If true, image is transposed so first dimension is the smallest
Returns:

An array of only the bounding box of the input.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
